column4: sorry for the repeat: i think that grub has overwritten the first 100mb or so of my documents drive (hdc1), how can i recover as much of the previous data as possible?
why would grub do that, and what makes you think it?
when i mount it (it should be a 110gb partition) all i see is a bunch of grub-related files, and it says the drive is about 100mb big
how is /dev/hdc partitioned?
just one big ext3 partition
how are you mounting it?
/dev/hdc1 /media/backup ext3 defaults,users 0 0
oh, is that from /etc/fstab?
when you run 'sudo fdisk -l /dev/hdc', does it show just the one partition? What size?
/dev/hdc1 start 1 end 14916 blocks 120053713+ id 83 system Linux
that looks fine
yes. What does 'df -h' say about /dev/hdc1 ?
Size 99M used 16M Avail 79M use% 17% Mounted on /media/backup
this is what i don't understand. i know the partition's bigger than 100mb :-S
is there any cherished data on that disk?
nothing lifethreatening but everything i've ever written for school, and everything i've ever pirated, haha. i CAN live without the data but i'd want to exhaust all the possibilities first
I'm not sure what the best strategy is. You could backup the entire drive block-by-block with dd, but you'd need 120GB of space...
you could also unmount and run e2fsck on it, but it's possible that you'll lose data if you let it "repair" stuff.
i can boost a hdd from somewhere else to back it up, how would i do it?
'cd /directory/with/lotsofspace ; sudo dd if=/dev/hdc of=hdc-image'
if=/dev/hdc or if=/dev/hdc1 ?
/dev/hdc (as this will save the entire hard disk, including the partition table and master boot record)
cool i just wanted to check - battery on laptop is about to die :-) cheers for all your help, will give e2fsck a go after backing it up. nice one :-)
another thing you could try is to look at it with gparted, see if you note anything strange
